content:
er 27, 2016
												Disclaimer: Not everything in this Review is said on a serious note. Some things are jokes and I hope these are obvious enough.Risk of Rain fails for me as a actual Rougelike. Not that it cannot be classified as one, but the feeling overall just does not fit. If you are here and expect a game that is fast and deadly, dont buy this game. This game relies purely on you, how you react ingame and how fast you can spam the jump button. Risk of Rain, is a platformer based on the roguelike concept. Your main task is to find a teleporter to reach the next world. And this task continues in said world, until you reach the end. In these worlds themself you will have to fight aliens that teleport in, sent in by the villain (or at the very least that is my theory as to how they get there).  These aliens then drop experience and currency. Currency which you can use on the various crates and shrines. Even random cryostasis chambers are there to provide you with items, should you have the currency for it. And if you should find a broken drone, it can be repaired with your currency just as well.But of course that is not all to the game. The crates, shrines and stasischambers contain items that, similar to "The Binding of Isaac" give you passiv and active abilities. Some allow you to gain health while damaging your enemies. Others  will make your overall health grow as you kill. Then again another ability grants you a double jump. And here comes the best about this: The abilities can stack when you find the same item you carry with you. A double jump transforms into a triple jump. You gain more health when you damage enemies. You get more max health when you kill. But of course, these are just the buffs. There are items you can use activly in combat. One of my personal favorites is the saw-blade. It does a massive amount of damage and can kill entire lines of enemies in one shot, in the earlier stages of the game.But now the game gets hard. Actually, it is hard from the get go. You look at the little bar on the top right and you see your impending doom slowly but surely rising to the top. Why? Because this game does it differently to others. Of course, you can choose between easy, medium and hard. But these only depict as to how hard the enemies are to kill and how many of them will spawn (and how fast they spawn). And this only gets worse the longer you play. As the longer you play, the difficulty rises. It begins with a stroll in the park and ends up in hell. And there is no way to avoid it, unless you do a speedrun of the game. Which is also not that easy as the teleporter is randomly generated on the pre-set worlds. Knowing how the world looks may help, but not knowing where the teleporter is, does not. And in the end it is a literally a maze where one turn can let you end up in a place that throws you out and you need to continue to search for the right path all over again.And as if it wasnt enough already that the game gets harder by the minute, that the landscape is kind of like a maze and that the teleporter spawns randomly, there are bosses as well. And they are not easy to kill. They can move and attack, just like the regular enemies can. Some are easy to cheesy (or in other words; Some cant get up a ledge and can be killed from above without being able to attack you.) and others will simply fly towards you to get the kill. Others have an AOE to make sure that you are not safe on that elevated platform of yours and others again will be able to teleport towards you to kill you right quick.But if you have done it all, gotten through all the teleporters, you will end up in the main ship. The one you were dropped off of in a capsule. And here is the main villain as well. But how do you reach him? Do the same thing you did before, but this time a bit different. Instead of finding the teleporter, you need to find the keypads infront of the doors. This will then again spawn in a bunch of enemies and at this point in time, surely a few bosses as well. And if you made it through all of it: The grand finale awaits.- Authors Note -Why did I say that this game fails as a Roguelike for me even if it can be classified as one?I experienced Roguelike games, and love them dearly. But one aspect was very important every time. And that little aspect is: You are never safe. But of course this is way to broad so let me explain:In the very flagships of Roguelike, which are "The Binding of Isaac": "Enter the Gungeon" and "Nuclear Throne", you could die as quick as you began to play the game, if you were not carefull enough. Die and lose it all, at any given point in time. The gameplay was quick, had you on your toes at all times possible and killed you as fast as it could. One of the most important things was that it didnt, unless you had found an ability or a health pack, give you any health back. A little detail that makes the games much harder and challenging.But in Risk of Rain this does not stand true. The very first thing that makes a roguelike, a rougelike is that you are never safe unless you cleared out the room or floor. In Risk of Rain however you can activate the teleporter, let the enemies spawn until its done and if you feel overwhelmed you can rope up and take a break and wait until your health returns to charge right back into battle.And that is what bores me about this game. I played all three of the mentioned Roguelikes and I have been frustrated. The more I played them, the more I raged. The more I failed, the more I wanted to wish hell and death on the devs for creating this piece of garbage. But after I calmed down I loved every second of what I experienced it. I guess I am a gaming masochist but still. And that is something, this game does not provide.This game is a stroll in the park no matter how high your difficulty is. You can get out of every situation with literally every character. The first one is actually the easiest. A dodgeroll helps you get out of the situation with immunity frames, you go up the rope and Boom: You are safe. But in a true Roguelike, you are never safe. You are never free from simply dodging damage unless it has to do with you actually dodging the damage. Which is absolutely possible in a 2D topdown roguelike. But not in 2D platformer roguelike. Only if you actually spam jump or dodgeroll, you can get out with no damage at all.So, do I think that Risk of Rain is a good game?- YesDo I think that Risk of Rain is a good Roguelike?- NoShould you buy it?- Yes

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2013
												Let me just start by saying that this game is AWESOMEAt it's heart, the game is an action platformer with a very old school feel.   There a few new school elements, the most obvious one being the item system.  If you have played Binding of Issac, this will be immediately familiar to you.  You acquire items that passively make your character more powerful throughout the game by using currency and defeating bosses.  This system is incredibly well done:  Almost all the items make an impact, yet there is nothing that feels overtly broken.  Even items that do not have an immediate, obvious application are revealed to be very powerful when paired with certain other item combinations or characters.The genius of the game really reveals itself as you unlock new characters.  There a few that feel like they are there as a novelty, but outside of those one or two, they are very well made with distinctly different feel and strategies.  The characters function similarly to ARTS characters with different base stats and 4 distinct moves all mapped to a different button.  Once again, it was shocking to me how much the game changed when using different characters.  It seems strange to say, but I was not expecting that level of depth. A lot of people will play the game for the carrot-on-a-stick nature of the unlocks, and the siren call of actually trying to beat the game.  Even after these tasks are accomplished, however, the game never really loses its appeal.  Having an amazing run and going through the entire game (which usually takes an hour or so) is just as satisfying the 10th time as it was the first.  When you start off, the notion of getting to the 3rd level can seem daunting, let alone beating the game.  The games learning curve can be somewhat steep, but when you come over the rise of competancy, you will really appreciate how robust the pacing, item system, characters and scaling difficulty of the game is.   Was an absolute joy ride from start to finish. 8.3/10

content:
er 4, 2013
												Risk of Rain is a frantic, fast-pased platforming/action game with a relatively short story and a HUGE degree of random variance. Playing as one of several characters (all "crew members" of a crashed delivery spaceship), you fight your way through mobs of enemies, relying on both skill and powerups scattered throughout stages to survive. These powerups are insanely random, each granting you an often-ridiculous bonus. Some are crazier than others, and many are so powerful or stupid that I can't even begin to describe them here. What's important, in my opinion, is that they're all fun to pick up. ...and you'd better be picking them up frantically, because the game's difficulty scales with time. The longer you take on a stage, the longer you dawdle trying to find treasure chests or shops with powerful items in them, the more powerful enemies will be on this stage and the next. The longer you spend fighting, in other words, the tougher the fighting becomes.A successful game of Risk of Rain usually lasts anywhere from about 40 to 60 minutes. The powerups on any given level vary wildly between playthroughs. The levels themselves can have multiple layouts and multiple styles. All of the characters--even the immediately-unlocked "Commando"--collectively provide a large number of different ways to make it to the next teleporter or die trying. In the end, the game is a crazy race against time to acquire powerups, kill enemies, and ultimately (hopefully) fight the final boss with a nonsensical menagerie of gear. This is without a doubt one of the most addicting games I've ever played. I highly recommend it.

er 26, 2013
												To call this game "2D Binding of Isaac" is to only scratch the surface, to get a vague grasp of what this game has to offer. Yes, it is somewhat like The Binding of Isaac in that there's things trying to kill you and items that make them less able to kill you, but  in my opinion, that's where the similarity ends. There's no unfairness or fake difficulty; much like Dark Souls, every death is your fault. You didn't move fast enough, you didn't time your dash skill, you didn't w/e. Every death in this game is a learning experience as you struggle for life on the hellhole planet you're stranded on. There's always something new in each playthrough, new nuances to learn, item combinations you happen upon, set in a constantly frantic, desperate struggle of you vs. the hordes.By far one of the funnest games I've ever played.

												:DISCLOSURE:  I received a copy for the purpose of review. That in NO way affects the outcome of this review. If a game is crap IMO I will say so. Thank you Steamified.Risk of Rain is an intense rogue like. The game play is fantastic classic 8/16 bit platformer action. You have four abilities to aid you in the journey of survival. Twelve different characters you can play. Three game modes that scale well, the easiest of which does not allow the saving of progress. Combine all this with TONS of items that offer passive and on use advantages. The item combos can get crazy, like in The Binding of Issac. AND if you get more than one of an item it will stack. This game is great if you have only 15min to play or 5 hours to play. Easy to pick up and get the hang of, but difficult to master no doubt. If you are new to rogue like games this is a great intro to the genre. Overall I would rate this game 8/10. It is a must play for any rogue like fan.

content:
ber 25, 2016
												Risk of Rain is a 2d platform rogue-like shooter with an increasing difficulty level that goes up according to time spent while playing: the longer your session - the harder it gets.Prepare to die. A lot.The game is not as easy as one might expect.Right off the bat you are put in a situation where a space cargo ship, UES Contact Light, in which you happen to be in, crashes on a hostile planet.You have 12 characters, all of which require you to do specific objectives ingame (beat the game on the hardest difficulty level, kill 3 specific bosses, obtain specific item combination.)Each character packs a four pack of abilities (So you will find the one that suits you)At the begining you have your first, already unlocked character - The Commando (My favourite of the whole shebang).A very versatile character that can handle most situations flawlessly.While playing, you collect items, scattered through chests that fell off the ship and shrines, that can require either your health or your money.Every item is a unique game changer. One can place fungus that heals you if you stand still for a few seconds, one amplifies your shots with bonus explosive damage, one can stop time when your health goes to a critical level and one item even gives you a second chance in case you die.The more items you get, the more powerful you become, and if you stack up items ( get more and more of the same one) the effect and amplification level increases (although some items have a limit on how many times the effect will improve).At the end of the game, each character has a different outcome. (They are really spine-chillin if you think of em afterwards) Here's the one of the Commando:"...and so he left, with everything but his humanity."The game also has multiplayer (online and locally).It can be a pain in the a$$ to get it working (it requires hamachi or tungle to work) but once you do, it is a whole lot more fun to beat the game with friends and die together :)P.SThere are artifacts, hidden throughout some levels, that change the game completely.One can give you the ability to choose a specific item of your choice instead of getting a random one, one will spawn a specific boss every 10 minutes and one will spawn only one random enemy type per stage. Great for making the game more customizable and can help you unlock characters. (But don't overuse them or the game loses the fun behind it) Overall Scores: Gameplay- 10/10Story - 8/10 (requires you to collect monster logs and even then it is mosly lore since characters do not speak here)Replayability - 10/10Multiplayer (once set) - 9/10  Final Verdict:  9/10


TLDR:
2d rogue like dark souls in space.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
18, 2015
Risk of Rain is a strategical Indie arcade-style shooter in which the player endures a constantly increasing difficulty of enemy forces while gaining experience to level-up, purchasing items and upgrades, and searching for a teleporter device that forces the player to survive a boss fight. The game shares an intriguing element with other titles in that the further you go and the more time it takes to get there, the more progressively powerful the endless waves of enemies become.Here are several reasons to give Risk of Rain a run while running for your life in-game:Leveling System - What was originally a foreign element to me now retains some clarity. I will be honest, I did not notice the fact that characters had a level when I began my first trek into the Risk of Rain world, especially since I was so overly focused on surviving the merciless onslaught of consistently spawning hostiles. It was only after my first few playthroughs that I truly noticed the leveling system’s effect on the game’s entirety, as it acts simply as an in-game marker on how well that run’s character was sustaining, and even acted as a gauge for comparison to the play time to see how the player was progressing during that particular playthrough. This is not to say, however, that the leveling system is a useless ploy. When a character levels up, they receive bonuses to health and damage, which is definitely useful throughout the game. What I mean to say is that the leveling system is unique in that it is not something the player has to focus on, though it can sometimes signify that the player has to either spend more time in defeating enemy forces or has time to find the teleporter due to the amount of work they put in.Character Selection - Each of the twelve characters in Risk of Rain has a completely unique playstyle to master. For instance, the Commando is a more tactful starting ally who is equipped with a pistol the deals medium damage and has a long range to which requires no cool-down for its use, a canon-like projectile weapon whose shots connect with multiple enemies within its line of fire, a basic combat roll which negates all damage within its arch, and a submachine gun burst that momentarily fires on both sides of the Commando player within a straight line. The Enforcer, however, is a close-range gunman equipped with a slow-firing short-range shotgun that has a slight knockback effect against enemies, a shield bash that is close-ranged and stuns all hostiles upon impact, a stance change in the form of a one-way shield block which increases fire rate for the given direction and redirects virtually all incoming enemy damage from the Enforcer’s front-however, the Enforcer cannot turn around whilst this mode is toggled-, and an explosive projectile launcher with a longer cool-down rate that has a decent knockback effect combined with explosive damage. There are eleven playable characters to unlock-with the Commando present from the game’s start-, but each requires a considerable amount of time to acquire, and even more time to master.Time-Based Increasing of Difficulty - As previously described, Risk of Rain utilizes a time-based difficulty system as well as the “Easy, Medium, and Hard” modes you would find within other titles. What sets this approach apart from the usual is that it completely and consistently influences the way you play. It is suggested that the player act quickly by locating the teleporter device upon spawning, but this requires said player to evade enemy forces persistently, subsequently causing them to be weaker when the end-stage boss fight does occur; on the other hand, because the enemies become increasingly difficult over time, grinding and exploration is somewhat limited to a shorter duration. This chaotic paradox raises a call to action within the player, in which the fast-paced gameplay is heightened to the condition that critical decisions must be made promptly. This system heavily drives gameplay, and this has been a favorite approach to gaming for me as well as a worthy mental and emotional adversary.Collectible Drops and In-Game Achievements - After countless deaths, the player should feel as though some sort of progression has been made, and the collectables found through each world achieves this satisfaction. A percentage of this progression comprises not only of how far one proceeds through each run but also of which upgrades the participating player unlocks during the playthrough. These, as well as collectible ‘Monster Logs,’ can be viewed in a catalogue from the main menu of the game. The in-game achievements create a sense of progression as well, and even allows the player to unlock additional items such as upgrades and additional characters by completing certain goals.TL:DR - Risk of Rain is one of those games that can be a chaotic mess and still retain its charm, which for some games is inaccessible. It is one of those games that you play as if it were embedded within an arcade cabinet and you have infinite quarters, without fear of failing. It is one of those games you just play: do not degrade yourself for not defeating an end-of-world boss because of a single mistake, do not worry about being a completionist while driving yourself mad just because an item did not drop when you needed it to. Risk of Rain is one of those games that deserves its claim as an Indie Gem, and that one should just play to play. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

content:
er 30, 2013
												Binding of Isaac and Terraria had a baby, Spelunky and Touhou had a baby, and those babies had a baby. This baby, through sheer chromosomal luck, has none of the bad qualities of its parents.That's right. With a Binding of Isaac unlock and generation system, Terraria's combat with a level-up system, Spelunky's sheer difficulty (and to an extent mechanics), and Touhou's blatantly colorful spam, I recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good 'ol Nintendo hard experience. Easily becoming one of my all-time favorite games as I play it more and more. Oh, and it has multiplayer in the Borderlandsy style of "HAHA, HAVING A SECOND PERSON ONLY MAKES YOUR SUFFERING WORSE!" if that's your kind of thing (I'm lonely and have no friends so I don't actually get to experience that.)

content:
10, 2016
												You want a hard as balls platformer with genuinely fun gameplay, as well as Binding of Issac style pickups and unlockables?  Buy this game.It has thoroughly beaten me up and taken my lunch money on more than one occasion.  It will punish you, and you will enjoy it. Because you will restart, determined to do better than the previous attempt.  It is extremely addicting, and as such, is fun as hell.Every class has a unique style to them. Each has a TOTALLY different method of traversing maps, taking advantage of terrain features, and destroying enemies in your path. I love it. A LOT of unrecognized love was clearly put into this game, and a lot of love has already been recognized.Get bored of the game for a bit? Burn out?  Read the enemy and item descriptions as you unlock them.Graphics: 2D. 9/10 for the little details, love'm.Sound: 8/10.  Some sounds are piddly, most are pretty great.Music: 10/10.  The music in this game will pull you INTO this game. It's repetitive game music, but it still has made some games intense as all hell.Story: Uh... there is a story... right. 2/10, I forgot about it, but it is relatively unimportant to the gameplay to be honest, which is never something I thought I'd say.Gameplay: 10/10. Your mistakes are your fault.  If you die, it is because you have not yet reached the appropriate level of 'git gud'. Your mistimed jumps, misfired shots, and hestitation can and frequently DO get you killed. This is quite a skillful game, and is a lot of effort to actually stay alive.Learn the characters, find out which one you like, then forget about it because you need to use all the characters to unlock all the things.  I fell in love with this game very quickly, and it is a great way to spend either five minutes, or an hour, depending on how lucky you are that time.Pro Tip:  The Engineer is the best class. ;)

y 19, 2015
												Ever seen a man get chased down by crabs and torn to limb from limb? I have. ♥♥♥♥'s horrifiying yo. First thing to go it's the dude's sense of cool, he hits the ground running and starts to panic. When he realizes he isn't fast enough to escape on foot the second thing to go is his sense of gravity. He starts pounding the jump key like it was his lover in the doggy-style postion. When he runs out of room to jump he lets out a primal chimp scream and jumps headlong into a hoard of hungry crabs, guns blazing. Welcome to Risk of Rain, buddy.The objective is simple. Find the teleporter on each level, flip the switch, hold the line until the timer counts to zero, then make like a tree and get the ♥♥♥♥ outta there. But there's a catch! If you decide you want to perform the ol' five knuckle shuffle just cause you've killed every enemy on the level you'd be making a grave mistake. This game gets harder with every minute that passes. Kind of like your uncle Jerry at your middle school play of Annie. If you die, that's it, no second chances. This isn't Super Mario, son. If you aren't on a full adrenaline-pumping-frenzy working your way through levels at redline speed you're next year's history lession. And that's the truth, Mac. Lucky for you that you've got some help. You can find items hidden in chests around the levels that will help you clear the levels. These items aren't used the condoms you find around your local park, no baby these are Evil Dead 2 Ash's chainsaw arm levels of cool. You can also use the online multiplayer if you can figure it out with friends to fight through the hoards of monsters waiting for you. This turns out less like you and your commando squad of badasses tearing through everything like you were Rambo's children and more like that one scene from Aliens. You know the one.You can get eaten as up to 12 different characters! That's a lot of flesh and metal for the monsters of the planet to sample so try to unlock them all!

content:
er 27, 2013
												I had been meaning to write this review for a long time now, but I couldn’t stop playing this game long enough to do it. Roguelikes and roguelike elements have been trending lately, and that’s not necessarily a bad thing. Risk of Rain houses a great challenge and addictive gameplay. Risk of Rain requires skill, reflexes, and luck to beat. Every character feels very distinct and they are all fun to play. Each character has four skills, three of which have cool downs, which you have to manage in order to survive. Damage comes in percents and the numbers get high.  Along with number crunching, the randomized items are an essential part of the game. These stackable items provide a number of bonuses, passive and active, that make survival possible. It is hard to describe what makes this game so intense and rewarding.  Difficulty increases as time goes on, so it becomes a tradeoff between risk and reward. Fully exploring a level could result in multiple boss spawns and death by elite level creatures, but rushing through the levels could leave you underpowered and lacking items. Your main objective is to find the teleporter in each level, but its location is randomized each time. Your starting point, chest placement, bosses, items, and overall location are all randomized as well. The intensity of the game never lets up because of the increasing difficulty, and it will take the right items and movements to beat the game. However, every playthrough feels like it’s teaching you something different: you will start to learn the layout of levels, the quickest routes, the main teleporter locations, and so on.If learning isn’t reward enough there are also plenty of unlockables. Besides the nine characters that need to be unlocked, there are a ton of items as well. These are all unlocked in a variety of ways that can make for some interesting challenges on top of the base game. Playing by yourself is great, but this is also a great local or online co-op experience, because teamwork is essential. Outside of the base game there are some logs and statistics to look through. While the item log seems to be less serious, the monster log provides some neat insight into the monsters of the game. The statistics page on the other hand, provides interesting insight into yourself and how much of problem this game has made out of your free time.Risk of Rain is hard to put down. The art and music are both really great, and the game feels solid and rewarding.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Risk of Rain. What a game. At first I was skepticle to try this game out being that I assumed it was just your average MOBA with some sort of twist to it like most games are nowadays. What you get is a lost soul stranded on a mysterious planet fighting for survival against a army of creatures that want nothing but your death. This game is intense, sweaty hands intense. You play as one out of eight character who's only like, 10 pixels tall against giant monsters that absolutely tower you while trying to fight off a horde of smaller monsters as well. You really do feel a sort of pressure on you while you play when you remember that the monsters only get stronger as time goes on, so you're left with the decision to scour the level for items or to just continue on before you become overpowered. This game is hard, it does not forgive and death will force you to start over, and I wouldn't have it any other way. This is a game for the skillful and the strong, anyone who can't face a good challenge will not survive long in this planet.I love the game. Since the game randomly generates the level to be different every time, you're contantly left guessing where the teleporter is. The wide assortment of items to attain is amazing as they all have different effects that help you in your survival, such as mushrooms that provide speedy healing or a rocket laucher that fires a barrage of missiles at your enemies. There are just so many possibilties that it you're constantly left playing the game over and over again because it's impossible to get the same playthrough twice. That leads me to another thing I love about the game, it's infinately replayable. Since there are so many items and characters you can unlock, it gets to be addicting as more of the game's content becomes avaliable.The Multiplayer mode is a complete blast. You would think that with teamwork, the game should be a breeze, but no. The more people are together at once, the more monsters come to rip you down. It's so much fun to combine you are your friend's unique abilities (assuming they all play different characters) and to coordinate together to survive as effectivly as possible. I always thought it was hilarious how sometimes your friends would get so desperate for items that they dive for every possible chest. Multiplayer adds a new layer of challenge as you now have decide to distrubute the random items evenly, or to have one man become the strongest and carry the rest of the team to survival.Now it's time for the bad.While it's fun and absolutely crazy when you're trying to fight off the hordes of them, after the big masses are dead, you're left with a few stragglers hidden somewhere in some corner of the map which becomes a chore to hunt them all down. One complaint I have with the game is how luck based it is, which I suspect isn't unreasonable considering the nature of the game, it's frustrating to spend your limited resources on a chest only to get some item that wouldn't help at all. There is very little incentive to use the shrines as they have such a high chance for failure, I would only use them if I had excess money on my way to the teleporter. Multiplayer is a pain in the ♥♥♥ to set up. This game uses the system where you have to connect to a friend via IP address. This system is very outdated and has only been nothing but a pain to get working. I cannot open my ports if my life depended on it which leaves me utterly unable to host games, leaving me to depends on my friends to play multiplayer, it becomes quite an inconveience to type in IP addresses for every person. At the very least, there should be an option to copy paste.Aside from those issues, this is an absolutely terrific game that deserves to be played at least once. It offers so much for the moddest price of $10. It's a real bargan to get so much play time from this game. Get it now!

content:
ry 12, 2014
												A lonely atmosphere. A struggle to survive. A breathtaking soundtrack.These are things to expect from Risk of Rain. I personally haven't experienced all there is in the game, but I've put enough time into it to confidently say that this game is something special, something we need to see more of.The story is found throughout the world and through the items you find. Nothing's completely concrete, and the speculation can be fun. At least, I find it fun.As a roguelike, you're punished on death, forced to start anew every time. The different classes and randomized map rotation, as well as some variables per map, allow the game to never quite be the same with each run through.The music, though? Glorious. That's my special word for special things. This game touched all the right notes for the soundtrack and has launched itself into my top favorites. And that's tough.The gameplay itself is hectic and fun as hell. Each class can handle each situation differently, although some can do so better than others. I personally like to use the Sniper. It's all about finding the right class for you.Overall, the game was done very well with just the right amount of everything a game needs. Platformers your thing? Roguelikes your masochistic desire? What the ♥♥♥♥ are you waiting for?

content:
er 20, 2014
												This game is always fun to play no matter what you are doing. Supposed to be studying for a test? Play Risk of Rain. In class? Play Risk of Rain. At a funeral? Play risk of rain.In all seriousness, Risk of Rain or RoR is a 2D side-scrolling rouge-like game where you fight unlimited and countless enemies to uprgrade and customize your character to survive the crazy world. There are multiple different classes of characters with unique abilities that set them apart from eachother. The world is always different through every play through of the game so it never gets old.There are random chests placed throughout the world that you open with money earned from killing enemies that give you upgrades or items that help you survive. The twist is once you die you die forever. You have to see how long you can manage to live and possibly beat the game if you are good enough but the game is VERY challenging.There are also acheivments and leaderboards in game and on steam that help you keep track of how good or terrible you are at the game.The game also offers an online co-op mode that you can play with up to four friends to help against the harsh enemies and worlds you explore.Conclusion: RoR is a rouge like adventure game that never gets old and is very addicting to the point were it can ruin your life.I would buy this game at full price so if it is on sale it is definitely a steal.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
												Risk of Rain is an indie platformer with a strong focus on fighting against large mobs of enemies, and some rouge-like elements such as unlockable characters and items. It's unique characteristic is that difficulty isn't tied with level progression, as the game allways becomes harder and harder as the clock ticks away.Art, soundtrack, hard difficulty and different playstyles for different characters are it's strong points. Perhaps you will enjoy being swarmed and being forced into kiting tactics rather than brute force or skill upgrades (there aren't any), perhaps not.Despite not being story-rich, the world is memorable, the soundtrack is one of the better ones (and one of my favourites), and the pace and progression is spot on for my tastes.The game is highly recommended if you're on the fence. If you dislike platrofmers or rage easily, probably avoid. Looking at the game on Twitch and YouTube, it's not easy to see what's so good about it. I had a *very* poor opinion about it, until i was convinced to try it. Immediately, my opinion went from utter dislike to surprised enjoyment.You kinda have to love games where you gotta move fast and react to chaotic swarms of enemies and projectiles rather than stalk things quietly and plan ahead (for most characters anyway, Sniper does it sligthly differently). If you enjoy very difficult, breakneck speed gameplay then this will satisfy you thoroughly. The game is very easy to play and very hard to beat. Beating it feels tremendously satisfying.The style, soundtrack and overall mood is somber rather than guts n' gore or slapstick. Like a weeping willow with a minigun, things get very violent but rather than being a hero or villian you're forced to fight as hard as you can just to survive.The story is largely ambiguous, told in bits and pieces of journal entries or item logs. Whatever the reasons brought you there, it's going to end in a lot of death.Items are numerous, humorous and range between very mildly useful and overpowered. With items and command artifacts it's possible to tweak gameplay difficulty and make the game nigh-on-impossible to beat. If you're into that sort of thing.The main gimmick of increasing difficulty as time goes by is executed very well and it's possible to win either by taking your sweet time and hoping to acquire as many useful doodads as possible or by rushing as fast as possible in order to clear later stages before the difficulty increases. It will make the first few attempts pretty hard but the game stays challenging longer that way. And as i've mentioned before, beating the game is an acomplishment!I've also mentioned the soundtrack being excellent but i'll mention it again!There's some bugs. The game engine was upgraded post release and as a results some old bugs were fixed and some new ones appeared. The level generation can occasionaly bug out and co-op play can suffer from port-forwarding problems or disconnects. Other bugs are pretty rare and minor but they get patched out occasionally.As a single player game Risk of Rain is almost a classic. As for multiplayer, well it's got a few problems and it's difficult to get it working until the bugs get fixed.

content:
y 4, 2014
												A lot of people say co-op is the way to play this game, but I've been having a lot of fun with it solo.  It's very deep and engaging, and once you've put some time into it it'll get its "one more run" hooks into you deep.  The problem is it doesn't put its best foot forward and it doesn't really teach you what to look for.  The starting class, the Commando, is straight forward but his dodge ability takes a lot of time to really master.  The second class, the Enforcer, is great for multiplayer but a little too slow and plodding for solo.  I've found that the most interesting classes unlock through random event spawns in the later levels, but they're either out of the way or blend with the rest of the scenery so that you need to be right on top of them to get the button prompt and realize they're actually gameplay elements.  If you want to have fun solo with this game, my recommendation is that you set it to easy, unlock all of the classes, and then play it on normal.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												I would recommend this game for the upgrade system alone. There are around a hundred items which are randomized, the interesting part being that they all work with each other and can stack with each other. This means that every playthrough, your style of fighting and main source of damage will change dramatically.One time you'll be rapid-firing a machine gun which has a chance of doing double damage, inflicting bleeding and fires faster the lower health you have - the next you'll be staying at a distance, firing the same machine gun on the same character but with mortars and rockets being launched at the same time, causing enemies to combust and leave pools of fire on the floor.The huge combination of items as well as the unlockables and large variety of characters and playstyles mean that not only is this game fun, but has a hell of a load of replay value. The main downsides for me are the lack in truly randomized levels (the layout itself stays the same, but the loot locations change) and the lag at later levels.A definite recommendation nonetheless, and a great game.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
r 5, 2014
												Risk of Rain is a level-based, rogue-like platformer that is several large boats full of action-packed fun. You land on an alien planet, perform diplomacy incredibly poorly by shooting everything you see until it explodes into the planet's currency, buy random loot, kill bosses and move on. Each runthrough is nicely randomized based on the loot you pick up and the character you select, and each character is well rounded with a MOBA-style 3 moves and 1 ultimate ability to help you get sh*t done. Platforming handles beautifully, all non-tank characters have movement abilities to make traversing the desolate environments flow nicely and last but not least, playing with friends is fantastic.Yes, It's a good game, 10/10 would reccomend, but it isn't perfect. The main issue I have with risk of rain is the time limit. Let me elaborate by saying that RoR doesnt really have a time limit; it simply gets harder for every 5 minutes of playtime. "but a game would be boring if it didnt get harder as you progress" I hear you bleat. Of course difficulty curve is important, but RoR literally gets harder the LONGER you play, rather than the further you get. You are rewarded for finishing the level as fast as you possibly can, which effectively penalizes exploration of the level. The more you d*ck around, the less likely you are to win. I, personally, do not consider this fun. The entire point is to prohibit players from collecting every possible upgrade and stop them from screwing the difficulty curve by farming early levels for gold and experience, but since experience increases exponentially as you progress and you lose all your money when you go up a level, I still fail to see the point of this gameplay tactic. I don't enjoy feeling rushed when I sit down to play a game.The only other major issue with RoR is that some enemies take WAY too much firepower to bring down. This small annoyance is compounded by the fact that you're on a clock. Playing this game, you will come to resent the tanky enemies so much for screwing up your perfect run. They aren't a challenge, they're not HARD to bring down, but you still need to and doing so is a CHORE. Eventually, as you play, you'll unlock a "relic" which allows you to start a new run with -90% health and 10x damage. This feels like the way the game was MEANT to be played, and when you get this extra the game becomes so unbelievably more playable you'll wonder aloud why it wasn't available from the FREAKING START!Risk of Rain is one of the better rogue-likes on the steam market, and I highly reccomend that you give it a go. Good luck trying to get multiplayer to work though!

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
y 6, 2014
												Should I get this game? How does it play? Does it keep me entertained? How about the music? The effects? Are those good too?Yes, yes they are.I didn't know about Risk of Rain until very recently, and its a damn shame I didn't find it sooner. This is without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played, and that's no exaggeration. The combat, the items, and the levels all feel just right. I can't describe it in any other way than just "right" but you'll see if you decide to spend your money on this masterpiece. The progression system is very nice. You start off with only one class, and that's the Commando. If played right, he is probably the easiest character to beat the game with, and again, that's something you find out very quickly upon playing. Through playing, you can unlock the other nine classes, The Enforcer, The Bandit, The Huntress, HAN-D, The Engineer, The Miner, The Sniper, Acrid, and The Mercenary. Each of these classes has skills completely unique to them and each class also has its own stat progression, such as health, armor, and damage. Some classes are definately more powerful than others, but not so much more powerful as that you feel the need to only play one class. Personally, I think that the two most powerful are The Mercenary, who you get for beating the game five times, and The Huntress, who you get for finding 15 monster logs, which drop at random. The multiplayer is still a work in progress, and is currently extremely difficult to get working properly. I can't wait for the final product to be released and enjoy co-op with ease. Risk of Rain is a very refreshing title that comes at a nifty price tag of $10, although I wouldn't hesistate to pay $30 or more for it. It is utterly flawless down to the very last pixel, and for that, has earned its place among my personal top 10 games list.Final Score- 10/10

												I previously didn't like this game that much, mostly because it ran at a glorious 5fps and it took over an hour to finish a single stage. Especially if you also dig games like The Binding of Isaac and are looking for something more heavy on the action.

content:
er 25, 2014
												This was a game I thought for sure I wouldn't be caught up in.I received this as a gift from a friend and upon playing it - it reminded me of Liero from back in the day due to the game mechanics and pixelation sort of graphics. But I got caught in a concept which the game follows. I was beaking my buddy the whole time about power ups and how they were nice in this game but it was lacking physical power-Ups like double jump's. Low and behold two minutes later I get two double jump power ups and my guy is literally jumping across the map. At that point I was in.The game play itself is good. The concept is you get one life, you run through the levels killing enemies first and fore most to get money to therefore in turn open these chests or "luck" statues for power Ups or items. As you kill you gain experience to level up. Power ups range from being able to double jump, to jumping further, to shooting faster, to shooting through everyone every fourth shot, cool-down time faster, every time you shoot maybe something explodes... literally I don't have enough space in this review to write every single power up out. The player starts with a "commando" character unit first and as you progress throughout the game or the more you play, the more character units you unlock. Every character has their set abilities (four of them) that cannot change but every character has different abilities. Items also have a cool down period just like the weapon abilities characters have, and the nice thing about items is that they are REUSABLE! What makes the game even better is that there is local multiplayer enabled (fakin' rights bud) and online multiplayer (ohhhhh faaakk yeah bud). So I definitely have to give it up to the guy who made this game because he tried thinking of it all. Oh yeah.... and it's controller supported :) (xbox controller as well as Logitech gamepad). Graphics are graphics as you can see in the preview of the game. To me they look like old Liero touch up's which is perfectly fine but my friend put it better : "This game reminds me of playing the original nintendo". After he said that - that's pretty much what I see now. The impact effects, the multitude of varying enemies with each their own power or attack and health, the backgrounds, the different levels all are nice and easy on the eyes, maybe even appealing to some. So I've talked quite a bit about this game, and mostly positive as it rightly is. Does it lack anything? Maybe for some. After unlocking a handful of characters I have to ask myself after being able to play for an hour every time I start a new game, what am I playing for? My stats aren't getting saved (I'm not sure if it's supposed to be saved every time you die or every time you simply start up the game) which sort of is irritating considering people like to see their stats. The game pretense is nice, it's all good but there is just that something more missing. Being able to build buildings in game? Maybe perhaps an RPG element where you can choose certain abilities? I think if this game had steam work shop or maybe some free add-ons to add to the game it would be perfect.I really want to give it my standard rating of 8 which I consider a rating of a good game, however I will have to give it a RATING 7.1/10.Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B- Overall  B-I feel the rating is fair because once you play this enough, you'll start wondering where is the motivation to play again. Unless of course a friend comes over or wants to play.Any chance of Risk of Rain 2?

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 10, 2014
												Risk of Rain is a somewhat Roguelike platformer. The game consists of five stages. Each stage is selected at random from a choice of ten to fifteen maps per stage, with the maps being variants on two or three actual landscapes. For example, for the first level, you will find yourself either in the Ancient Forest or in the Dried Lake, and each one of those has several variants.Throughout the game, enemies spawn and attack you, the type of which are determined by the map you're on, and the number of which are determined by how far the game timer has progressed. It starts at Very Easy, Easy, Medium, and Hard, and eventually progresses to I SEE YOU, I'M COMING FOR YOU, and HAHAHA.At around HAHAHA, you might start having two or three boss monsters spawning with the normal enemies at random.As if this isn't bad enough, you're pretty fragile and horribly, horribly outmatched by the unending waves of enemies you face. Your weapons are laughably weak in comparison to your foes' attacks, and the fact that there are Elites and Phantasms which ramp the power up to even more ludicrous heights only makes the game more inherently unfair.You kill enemies to collect currency and experience. Experience gains you levels, with the usual "make everything better" that comes with levelling. Coins can be used to unlock treasure chests or sacrificed at shrines.The items you gather will make your life a little easier. Not much. Sometimes, negligibly so. But enough negligible boosts can really stack up after a while.This game follows the Goldeneye model of achievements. Each achievement you earn comes with an in-game unlock - some will unlock items that will be able to drop from thereon out, some will unlock new characters, like the specialized and challenging Sniper, or the adorably toxic Acrid.All in all, I have ground my face against this game for hours and hours, have only won a handful of times, and have loved nearly every minute. This is not for the Facebook Games generation, this is for the motherfudgers who thought Contra was a good time, even if they never could get anywhere without the Konami Code.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
y 24, 2014
												Risk of Rain? Pfft, more like Risk of PAIN. Because, you know, you'll die a lot in the game.Actually, it's not as much of a risk as it is a certainty. Hold on, let me try again.*ahem*Risk of Rain? Pfft, more like Certainty of Pain. Wait, no, that's crap. Hm, synonyms of certainty...inevitability...destiny? Destiny of Pain? That sure sounds dark, though. Although I guess it fits with the game...where was I going with this again?Dammit, okay, so Risk of Rain is about an interplanetary cargo ship that gets attacked by aliens over a deserted planet. The ship crashes, and you, playing as one of about a dozen different classes, have to, with the help of the cargo you find scattered across the planet, defend yourself against the native creatures and find your way back to the ship. It's a 2D jumpey-shootey platformer that is kind of sort of roguelike-ish; the areas you go to are more or less random, with the locations of the teleporters and items - and the items themselves - being fully randomized, but each area has only a couple of variations. This is not a bad thing - once you play through an area enough times, it's easy to figure out the general layout, meaning that it's potentially easier to find the teleporter to the next area. This saves time, and in Destiny of Pa Risk of Rain, time is not on your side.The longer you spend in the game, the harder the game gets. More enemies spawn more rapidly, the enemies become stronger and tougher, and at higher difficulties, boss enemies can spawn in the middle of a level, instead of only at the end. This not only keeps the game's difficulty up, but it also forces you as a player to keep moving forward. Do you farm enemies and search for items, or head straight for the teleporter to prevent the difficulty from rising any higher than it needs to?The game also features both local and online co-op, which is great, but sadly both methods have their own problems. Getting online co-op to work requires more than passing knowledge of computers, and local has every player sharing one screen, which makes exploration difficult. When it works, though, it can be a blast - exploration and monster-killing become much easier with multiple people, and working in a team allows the more specialized classes, such as Sniper and Enforcer, to shine.Risk of Rain has good controls (the game is perfectly playable with either a keyboard or a gamepad), plenty of things to unlock and discover, and a punishing difficulty level that keeps it from getting boring but is never discouraging. Even though you start with one basic (albeit well-rounded) class, the Commando, getting the other classes offers a nice challenge on top of the gameplay itself, and each class plays very differently from the rest. The game is a ton of fun and you should buy it.

content:
2014
												Risk of Rain is damn hard, you will die a lot in it, and these deaths will be unfair. It will require every ounce of attention, time management skills, and luck. The difficulty ramps up over 40 minutes, and after that the game is laughing in your face, throwing everything it has at you like Freddy Krueger doing his one joke stand-up comedy routine, and his one joke is having you drown in a vat of snakes and bugs.But the reason for my recommendation is at the point of the game where you're so buffed that no monster, big or small, can touch you. The part where kills gain you extra maximum hit points, and you're taking out four of these ♥♥♥♥ers every few seconds or so. The part where you have so many drones you're raining bullets into faces and watching them all go down, firing frantically while the horde is held back by your absolute, undeniable firepower, being showered in gold, health, and experience, knowing that you cannot be stopped and that their absolute best is going to have a hell of time killing you.And then you get ganked by some horrible little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you didn't see in time to deal with.If you're not that much into Roguelike-type stuff, maybe skip this and come back to it later on. If you're looking for a co-op game, it requires port forwarding and is not as much fun as doing it alone. Other than that, it's glorious and frustrating and compelling.

content:
, 2016
												Risk of Rain is a fun rogue-like game where you gain experience and gold from killing the endless waves of monsters on every level until the boss is found and destroyed. You will find items that have unique powers which will make you more powerful with each one you find, however time is against you; as time goes on so does the difficulty of the monsters. That is the risk on every level while trying to explore every corner to make sure you get all the items, however the monster density increases and so does their strength. There are a ton of items to find and numerous of different characters you can unlock which each having their own playstyle and ability. The game also has multiplayer (use Hamachi) which adds to the chaotic fun. The graphics and the music in this game are really good as well; if you want to try a rogue-like game this is one of the better ones to start off with.

content:
ry 13, 2014
												It's hard to judge a platformer with only 10 levels to offer, usually one would say that it is lacking in content. However, when you factor in the 16 possible combinations of the first 4 levels, the myriad of variations each level has, and how item drops are completely random that gives passive buffs to the player, plus the inclusion of 9 unlockable classes and 1 default class.. You have this roguelike platformer where no 2 play throughs are the same.The gameplay is really fantastic, lending itself to real frantic action with tons of tough enemies and impossible bosses. It has a unique mechanic of cranking the difficulty up as time passes, and so it becomes a wild race against time to get as many items as possible in as little time as possible to keep you alive. There are over 100 items to pick up with more than a handful of them being deployable during the game for added effects.It's not just the gameplay that is great, the 2-D spritework and the forlorn-sounding music complete the experience of playing this game. It looks great, it plays great, there is a lot of depth and challenge to be had. I would say that this is one of the best Rogue-likes to come out in 2013. Go pick it up.

content:
4, 2014
												A fast-paced and unforgiving 2D platformer-shooter with 8-bit, pixel graphics.The storyline is rather thin, but solid enough to relay to the player who you are and what you're doing. A stranded pilot on an alien planet and trying to not die, respectively.The gameplay starts off nice and easy, but gradually picks up the pace, ramping up the difficulty exponentially. Apart from 2D platforming and shooting things, this game can very well be categorized as a rogue-like. With permanent death, unforgiving difficulty and a lot of randomized items to aid you in combat, fans of rogue-likes and fast-paced action alike will appreciate Risk of Rain.There are 10 classes to be unlocked, each with 4 distinct and unique abilites. The variety allows for an amazing amount of play styles and strategies. Combined with the at times randomness of items and shrines to waste your money on, players will need to hone their skills and rely on luck as well, if they are to escape this hostile and indomitable planet.

content:
y 11, 2015
												Risk of Rain is a roguelike action-platformer...I guess? Really I can't keep up with all these crazy genres/sub-genres anymore. Mainly the game works like this:1. You crash land on a planet filled with hostile alien life-forms.2. You must seek out the teleporter.3. You have to survive for 90-120 seconds while killing these aliens and the stage boss.4. You acquire items that unlock additional abilities.5. You can either escape the planet or continue searching for items to become a God of alien-destruction.6. You never get a normal night's sleep again.7. You You You You You You You You You YouHonestly I'm not sure why I enjoyed this game as much as I did. I'm usually not a fan of roguelikes. While I understand and appreciate the work that goes into designing a game in this style, it just seems like 80% of indie titles are some variance of "get stronger...but don't die or you'll lose everything!" Risk of Rain however, it really clicks with me, and I've barely scratched the surface.Let's start with the difficulty. RoR can be a challenging game, especially when played on the harder setting, using particular artifacts, and imposing restraints (not acquiring particular items, tougher class, etc). There's a lot of flexibility that goes into this game. Through experimentation and practice, you eventually hit the "How could you ever die?" level, that's a good indicator to change things up for your next play-through. Despite the limited number of stages and aliens, the game maintains its freshness on subsequent play-throughs. This is attributed to good scenario design. Actually I take that back, since scenarios are usually created through a combination of artifacts and randomness. Still, a lot of what makes each stage great is what can happen, and the items you find leading to subtle changes in your overall strategy. Surviving is important, but you also have to kill everything. Sometimes aliens/bosses can be "herded" by allowing them to spawn on platforms. Teleporting elites can mess with this strategy however.  It's also possible to get trapped by a swarm of aliens, forcing you to make the most of your limited invincibility moves to get away/chip at the crowd. Then there's the immense satisfaction of when everything comes together. You're shooting enemies with lasers, rockets, bullets, missiles, and a bunch of other random crap all at the same time while viewing a parade of numbers. Taking out 40+ enemies at once with a huge attack is also quite amazing. I especially enjoy playing as the mercenary. He has a couple invincible moves and a spin-slash that works sorta like a jump. Eventually I get the cooldowns so low I can mash the invincible moves every second, and constantly spin-slash through huge enemies while never touching the ground. I could go further, believe me I really want to, but I have to get my life back. Risk of Rain devours my free-time, and I still have several hundred other games to play (plus a job and some other stuff that is probably necessary). This game might click for you as well, which would be both great and terrible.

content:
y 24, 2014
												I admit. I was a bit reluctant at first to pick up this game. But once I did, I instantly knew that it was an incredibly good decision on my part. I fell in love within the first few minutes. Imagine a game that takes you, the player, into a cakewalk. You find a cupcake here and there and maybe one or two spoiled ones. Not so bad, right? Then suddenly, the cupcakes turn into bricks. You wonder, "Wait, why did these cupcakes suddenly get hard?". You go around finding brick after brick, wondering when you'll find another cupcake. Then to your delight you find an entire damn chocolate cake. And not that cheap crap, either. This is the premo stuff imported from a five-star in Germany. You go to town and dig right in. Afterwards, you realize there's someone behind you. You turn around and what do you find? None other than the dark lord of hellfire and cats, and he's got a legion of pitchforks behind him that are going to be stuck somewhere; and there's no way in hell you'll find any cupcakes now. Now imagine that every five minutes that same dark lord clones himself and his legion threefold; those pitchforks ain't there for decoration, either.That's what it's like playing Risk of Rain. An amazing experience of continuously being challenged against an ever increasing difficulty and number of foes. And that's on the single-player, too. You can invite three other friends with you so that you're not the only one being stuck by pitchfork-wielding cats.The cool thing about this game is the wide-range of character selection, as well. Each character is its own experience to be played, along with their own pros and cons. Most of these characters must be unlocked by completing a certain achievement, making quite a few of them difficult to unlock.You can play as:A drug addictA masochistA hoarderA poacherA robotA nerd with turrets for friendsA gold diggerAn assassinAn animalAnd a guy who likes swords(Respectively: Commando, Enforcer, Bandit, Huntress, HAN-D, Engineer, Miner, Sniper, Acrid, Mercenary)If you haven't already, then pick up this game. Seriously. Ignore the 78 metacritic score; it's complete bull.This is a game that will give you hours and hours of entertainment with extreme amounts of replay value. I got RoR during the Steam Christmas sales, but I would gladly pay $10 for it. I know that as soon as I pick up the controller and launch Risk of Rain, I'm going to be stuck for hours at a time. And I wouldn't have it any other way.On a scale of one to ten, I rate this game: HAHAHAHA

												Risk Of Rain is a brilliant platformer/rouge-lite, the main thing with this game that pulls me into this game is how easily I can switch from being under-powered to over-powered and then back again in split seconds. (mostly from getting too cocky when I have certain power-ups. :P) It's genuinely a hard game and I love it for that reason. The music is a selling point as well, sort of a rocky/electronic/ambient thing.The difficulty scales just right for me, it gives me a good 2-5 minutes to do what i need to do in each level, so I can do either a quick pick-up-and-play run or i could do a good 40 min run to (rarely) get to the last level. Plus this game actually makes me want to collect every single power-up and monster log just for the little storys you get alone.The only gripe I have with it is how complicated it is to connect with friends, when I want to connect with a friend I have to use a program called Evolve[evolvehq.com] that gives me and my friends a temp IP address, and even that fails some of the time.All in all, this is a solid game that rates highly on my games list.

r 6, 2014
												Fun Action-Platformer with some mild rogue like elements. There is a random selection of Arenas, but the overall maps are consistent. Enemy, Item and Teleporter spawns are randomized and depend in part on your unlocks and playtime as the game difficulty increases over time for each run.Controls are tight and work best on gamepad. Difficulty goes from challenging to really, really hard. A run might be short-lived in the beginning but will probably not be much longer than an hour, at that point you either reached the final stage or the game difficultly will have outpaced your character's ability. On that note the final boss is aggravatingly annoying and the reason why I will probably not play this game any further.I enjoyed all the classes I unlocked and had a good time in coop. After 5 hours there are still plenty of items and class combinations to explore, along with some good upgrades in difficulty. Overall great game with a poor designed final stage.

y 14, 2014
												Risk of Rain is an addicting action-based platformer with a healthy dose of challenge. Solo or Co-op, the game is a blast because the game gets progressively harder as you play it! With the idea of collecting power-ups and perks in a struggle to get more powerful and balance out the constant rise in difficulty, you and your friends will find yourselves getting constantly bombarded with more and more enemies and bosses until you die or beat the final stage.    It has great replayability due to the multiple characters to unlock (each with their own very unique playstyles!) and the ever-growing random buffs and perks you unlock by doing challenges! It also features fluid pixel art and great soundtrack to boot. Gameplay is smooth and easy to pick up, but has a decent amount of depth in terms of timing your skills right.    If you like the sound of any of that, I definitley recommend Risk of Rain :)

content:
7, 2015
												At first, I was sceptical about this game. Indie 2D platformer with roguelike elements and pixel artsy visuals - how original is that, am I right? Still, I was kind of drawn to it.I got it as a gift from a stranger some time ago, and it was basically just sitting in my library ever since. Recently, I've been looking for something new to play and I've decided to give it a go. I learned very quickly how wrong I was…What is it about?   Storywise, there's not that much to talk about:  Your character somehow survived the explosion of the space cargo ship. You crash landed on an unknown planet, which is bad enough by itself. Unfortunately, the whole place is swarming with all sorts of strange, deadly creatures. As you can probably imagine, none of them is what you'd call "friendly". You need to get out of this place…   Leaving the planet is not as easy as one would hope. There are 6 (somewhat) randomly generated levels, each harder than the previous one. To get to the next level, you need to find a teleporter, activate it and then survive another 90 seconds, during which you fight the boss and waves of enemies. Only after killing everything, you can progress to the next level and repeat the same procedure.   Other than your 4 basic combat skills, there are many different passive and active items to be found  These can be bought with the money you've earned by slaughtering monsters native inhabitants. However, it takes a while to get those $$$, which is unlucky, because the game is getting tougher over time. That means you have to decide pretty soon whether to grind for a few minutes and become as OP as you possibly can, or just try to speedrun the whole thing with only a few items. It's your call.What's good...   Even with multiple attacks, controls and the whole combat model is really easy to get into. I've played with a controller most of the time, but it's absolutely fine with keyboard too.  It feels nice and fluid. Chaining attacks is fun, but it also requires a bit of a planning to pull off, so it's not just downright brainless button mashing. Also, difficulty increasing over time is a nice little mechanic and takes the game to a whole new level (heh). Same goes for collecting and stacking different items. All in all, the game actually requires quite a bit of tactical thinking.   Next, I love the amount of content they've put into the game. There are about 100 items total and it takes a while to unlock and find all of them. More than that, you can unlock 11 additional characters. All of them have their unique skill set, allowing for different playstyles, meaning very different experience. Thanks to this, and randomly generated levels, the replayability of this game is insane.Besides, there are diary logs, describing some of the monsters you've encountered, and also "shipping details" for all of the items you've found so far. These add more little details to the story and enviroment, making you more invested into the universe you still know nothing about. Moreover, the atmosphere is just wonderful. Pixel art style is spot on and the soundtrack by Chris Christodoulou is just stellar (I'm done with puns now, I promise…).    While it can start to get a little bit ridiculous after 20 minutes or so, I enjoy that. Not being able to see your character through the mix of enemies, health bars, damage values, effects and particles may be stressfull for some…but making it out alive is veeery satisfying, cathartic even. When thing go wrong (and the frequently do), I always feel like I know exactly how I screwed up, despite all of the chaos and randomness. Don't get me wrong, this game is REALLY HARD and will kill you again and again and again… but it still feels more fair than any other rogue-like I've played.On the other hand, beating this game for the first time was one of the most rewarding gaming experiences I think I've ever had…What's not so good…   There are only a few little problems, but I feel like I should mention them anyway.First, the Steam overlay doesn't work at all with this game, which surprised me. That means no screenshots on Steam. Obviously, you can still use the OS's built-in print screen function, but it's a shame that you can't share it with you friends that easily and basically support the game more. Not sure what to think about that. Also, full controller support and Big Picture mode support would be swell. That's pretty much it, nothing else to complain about.Conclusion.Risk of Rain is rock hard, yet fair and fun to play. It combines several interesting mechanics in a very cool way, and the amount of content and replayability is amazing. The world of RoR is eerie, strange and beautiful at the same time, thanks to it's visual style and great soundtrack.If you're a fan of rogue-likes, or hard games in general, you should just buy this game right away - it is definitely worth of both your time and your money. If you are short-tempered however, I would advice you to reconsider.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												Risk of Rain is a 2D platforming shooter that puts you on a hostile planet full of alien creatures. The enemies are randomly added and spawn in. While the game has random levels, after 7+ hours of play, you start to recognize that there are random levels with extra frills on them to make them feel as if they were generated. The object of each level is to make it to the teleporter that is randomly placed somewhere on the map. Once you activate it, you need to survive for 90 seconds. A countdown clock appears and soon after a boss emerges and you get swamped with enemies that spawn into the area. A lot of times they spawn on you. Once the 90 seconds are up, then you need to kill the remaining creatures including the boss before you hop in the teleporter to the next level.Along the way you'll find plenty of items and power ups that do some interesting and fun things. Some give you a chance to make enemies freeze, bleed or slow down. Others help with regenerating your health. Another will a barbed wire shield around you while others turn dead enemies into ghosts that will fight for you. There are dozens of these items. You don't just keep one, they stack, so you can end up with a dozen on you and not just that, but if you get the same one on the same play through they increase the effectiveness. Two feathers means you can now jump twice in the air instead of just once.Its more than just passive items, there are usable items that will do things like shoot a cluster of missiles, replenish your health or unlock all the treasure chests on screen. These items have a very long cool down timer, usually around a 45 - 60 seconds. You can even spend money to repair drones that either shoot bullets, lasers or heal you with a green beam. They're so nice to have, especially two of them.You'll find these items from beating bosses, in treasure chests, stores, imp statues and chance statues. The stores give you a choice of three items. Once you buy one, all three disappear. The treasure chests give you a random item and cost gold to open it. The chance statues and imp statues also cost gold. As you get to higher levels, the amounts increase. The chance statues are just that, a chance to get an item. Sometimes these statues cost you health. The more you try, the higher the price. The imp statues release five imps that simply run away from you and you need to kill them all to get your prize. These are all ways to keep the game interesting.The controls are simple, you can move left and right, climb up and down on ladders and jump. Each character has four abilities. Three of which have cool downs. So you have unlimited ammunition, just a timer before you can use them again. To start, you've got a standard fire button that shoots a short burst each half a second. Its not like a machine gun, but at least you can hold down the trigger. Rapidly pulling the trigger will shoot faster, but only if the gun animation has gone away. So not all characters will shoot faster. Depending on the character you have all sorts of range and damage output.From there, you've got a defensive move. The commando has a combat roll to go through enemies.  The enforcer has a shield that he will drop down making him incredibly slow, but protected  from the front. The Bandit has a smoke bomb that makes him invincible for three seconds. Enemies stop chasing you and so on. There are 9+ other characters, but well after 7+ hours, that's all I was able to unlock. These different characters really feel a lot different from one another.What I really don't like is a few times if I want to quickly turn and fire. I'll turn enough so my character will start moving the other way, but when I fire, he will turn around to shoot, then keep running the way he was directed. It seems to happen pretty consistently, especially as the bandit. Even dropping the guardian's shield he will turn around to drop the shield. It is just odd. It has cost me lives and wasted abilities, not to mention special weapons that I need to wait 45 seconds to reuse.You have a good amount of health and it regenerates very slowly over time. Of course every enemy has a good amount of health too. This makes weapons feel pretty powerless. It takes several shots to take down lesser enemies and with larger enemies that have more health, I found myself sitting there just waiting. Perfectly safe, but waiting far too long for my character to kill them. Luckily there is a leveling up system that will give you more health and damage output, but as the clock ticks away, the enemies get stronger and more powerful. Its just really dull having to kill a clump of five strong enemies all batched together. I could put a rubber band on my 360 controller and walk away for a minute. The game just feels like one big grind. You can always get items that add a chance of homing missiles or a chance of mortars, but even then it doesn't help all that much.The game feels slow getting from point A to point B. I'd dread knowing that I'd have to go back somewhere. The character feels like he moves slow, the weapons feel powerless. Its not quick action like Contra or Mega Man. Its all deliberate to prolong the experience. You have a nice wide view of the area, so you get a better sense of where to go, because your character is so slow that if you zoomed in on the action, it would take that much longer to find where you're going. I'm just happy that the experience and gold that falls from enemies automatically flies to you from wherever it is. Having to pick it up would be painful.Like in the real world, you only have one life. When you die, that's it you need to start over, but hopefully you've made it far enough on your previous play through to unlock new items that you'll find in future play throughs. It always drives you to keep going like oo a new thing. Now all I need to do is play again and hope to randomly find it somewhere.The enemies are pretty brainless, that's what allows them to just let me shoot them. I think because they all have so much health they need to be brainless. There are some enemies smart enough to jump up onto platforms to follow you and chase you around, but they're not smart enough to jump over gaps. Floating jellyfish will seek you out, fly through platforms and dart toward you at some point. The bosses are pretty iffy as well.When you get to the teleporter and enemies start transporting in, I found myself getting randomly overwhelmed, because the foes would spawn in on top of me. So then I'd have to run away and keep moving for the 90 seconds or I'd quickly be dead. You don't get brief invincibility when you get hit. Enemies can keep right in you attacking unless you're fast enough to run away or use one of the defensive tactics like roll, smoke bomb or drop a shield. Even if you get good at running away, at some point, there are enemies that can teleport straight on you. Just poof, they're now in you. Do you shoot left or right? Well you occupy the same space, so your guess is as good as mine.As for the music and graphics, both are great. The music excels at being something spacy and other worldly. The graphics look small and old school. I think these two came together to improve the experience I had and made me want to stay in game, because I know it was a struggle against the grind.If you want to play cooperatively, you'll need to have a friend with you, have a LAN connection or an IP address. There is no play through Steam. I'm not sure if I enjoyed the game. Even playing with a friend, it wasn't that fun. I hate to be the only person that didn't enjoy the game. I don't feel like I had fun playing the game, when this game should be right up my alley. I like random stuff, I like good combat and somewhat random levels, but I just feel like I would have enjoyed it more with a faster pace.
